skill.name: ghe-checkpoint
skill.description:
POST a progress checkpoint to the CURRENTLY ACTIVE thread. Saves work state without changing phases. Requires an already-claimed in-progress thread.

USE THIS SKILL WHEN:
- User says "post a checkpoint", "save my progress", or "save checkpoint"
- User completed a milestone and wants to record it
- User encountered a blocker and wants to document it
- User is about to take a break and wants to save state
- Meaningful state change occurred during work

PRECONDITION: User must already have an active (claimed, in-progress) thread.

DO NOT USE THIS SKILL WHEN:
- User wants to SEE status (use ghe-status)
- User wants to START work on new issue (use ghe-claim)
- User wants to FINISH current phase and MOVE to next (use ghe-transition)
- No active thread exists (must claim first)

EXAMPLES:
- User: "Post a checkpoint" â†’ Use ghe-checkpoint
- User: "Save my progress, I finished the authentication module" â†’ Use ghe-checkpoint
- User: "I need to stop for now, save my work" â†’ Use ghe-checkpoint
skill.summary: Save progress checkpoints to GitHub issue threads without changing work phases.
skill.author: Emasoft

security_audit.summary: All static findings evaluated as false positives. The skill is a legitimate GitHub workflow checkpoint system that posts progress updates to issue threads. Detected patterns (URL fields, timestamp formats, documentation examples) are benign metadata and documentation, not malicious code. No command injection, data exfiltration, or credential access detected.

content.value_statement: This skill posts structured progress checkpoints to GitHub issue threads, enabling teams to track work milestones, document blockers, and maintain persistent work state across sessions without interrupting current work phases.
actual_capabilities: Post formatted progress checkpoints to GitHub issue threads
Save current work state including completed tasks, in-progress items, and pending work
Document blockers and next actions for team visibility
Sync progress updates to memory bank for persistent context
limitations: Requires an active (claimed) in-progress thread to post checkpoints
Only works within GitHub Elements (GHE) workflow ecosystem
Cannot transition between phases (use ghe-transition for that)
Cannot view or check status without an active thread

use_cases.title: Daily Standup Progress Tracking
use_cases.description: Post daily progress updates documenting completed tasks and current blockers directly to issue threads for team visibility.

use_cases.title: Milestone Documentation
use_cases.description: Record significant project milestones and completed work phases to maintain audit trail and progress history.

use_cases.title: Session Handoff Preservation
use_cases.description: Save detailed work state before ending sessions so work can resume seamlessly in future sessions.

best_practices: Post checkpoints at meaningful milestones to maintain accurate progress history
Document blockers immediately when encountered to preserve context
Include next action in checkpoints to ensure smooth session resumption
anti_patterns: Posting checkpoints without meaningful work updates reduces documentation value
Skipping checkpoints before breaks loses important work state context
Using checkpoints instead of transitions when phase completion is intended

faq.question: What is the difference between a checkpoint and a transition?
faq.answer: A checkpoint saves work state without changing phases. A transition completes the current phase and moves to the next phase. Use checkpoints for saving progress, transitions for phase completion.

faq.question: Can I post a checkpoint without an active thread?
faq.answer: No. You must have an active (claimed, in-progress) thread first. Use the ghe-claim skill to claim a thread before posting checkpoints.

faq.question: Where are checkpoint reports stored?
faq.answer: Checkpoints are posted to the GitHub issue thread as comments and also saved to the GHE_REPORTS directory in flat file format with timestamp-based naming.

faq.question: What information is included in a checkpoint?
faq.answer: Checkpoints include work log, completed tasks, in-progress items, pending tasks, files changed, commits, current branch, blockers, and next action items.

faq.question: Does posting a checkpoint affect my current thread state?
faq.answer: No. A checkpoint only saves progress information. It does not change the thread phase or claim status. You remain in the same phase after posting.

faq.question: Can I edit a checkpoint after posting?
faq.answer: The checkpoint is posted as a comment on the issue. You can edit the comment directly on GitHub or post a new checkpoint with corrected information.
